docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama told an audience of nurses on Thursday that the number of uninsured Americans rose by nearly 6 million during the last 12 months.

headline.main: Obama Keeps Up Health Care Push, Citing Uninsured
headline.print_headline: Obama, Reinforcing Health Care Message, Says It Is ‘Time to Act’

docs.snippet: President Obama told an audience of nurses on Thursday that the number of uninsured Americans rose by nearly 6 million during the last 12 months.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and JEFF ZELENY

docs.lead_paragraph: Who needs a marketing department when the leader of the free world plugs your company -- gratis, no less -- in a prime-time, nationally televised address? Executives at Geisinger Health System in Danville, Pa., and Intermountain Healthcare in Salt Lake City could be excused for wondering as much on Wednesday, when President Obama gave their hospitals a shout-out in his speech to Congress.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama cites Geisinger Health System in Danville, Pa, and Intermountain Healthcare in Salt Lake City, Utah, in televised health care speech; says hospitals offer high quality at low costs (S)
docs.snippet: Who needs a marketing department when the leader of the free world plugs your company  --  gratis, no less  --   in a prime-time, nationally televised address?     Executives at Geisinger Health System in Danville, Pa., and Intermountain Healthcare...

docs.lead_paragraph: Pencils ready? As Democrats descend from their general euphoria over President Obama's address to Congress, now comes the boring budgeteering. How to deliver on his promise to renovate the health care system at a 10-year cost of $900 billion without adding to the federal deficit?
docs.abstract: Pres Obama's health care address leaves House lawmakers with task of delivering on his promise to retool health care system at 10-year cost of $900 billion without adding to federal deficit; Obama's strategy of imposing new fees on high-end insurance plans is rebuff to House committee plan to impose surtax on high-income Americans; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Pencils ready?      As Democrats descend from their general euphoria over President Obama's address to Congress, now comes the boring budgeteering. How to deliver on his promise to renovate the health care system at a 10-year cost of $900 billion...

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans have long argued that revamping malpractice laws can cut health costs. But when President Obama announced Wednesday night that his administration would establish pilot projects intended to reduce lawsuits against doctors, Representative Charles Boustany Jr., the Louisiana Republican who delivered his party's response, sounded skeptical. ''We hope he's serious,'' said Mr. Boustany, who is a heart surgeon.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama's plan to reduce lawsuits against doctors is middle path between parties; wants to encourage states to apply for federal grants to look at other ways of curbing malpractice suits; hopes to reduce practice of 'defensive medicine,' which drives up costs when doctors order unnecessary test to guard against being sued; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Republicans have long argued that revamping malpractice laws can cut health costs. But when President Obama announced Wednesday night that his administration would establish pilot projects intended to reduce lawsuits against doctors, Representative...

docs.lead_paragraph: How did the television commentariat react to President Obama's prime-time address on health care? Bill O'Reilly, for one, thought it should have been shorter. ''Way too long,'' actually, is how Mr. O'Reilly put it. And his verdict matters, at least to the five million viewers who watched his Fox News Channel program on Wednesday night. His nightly audience, averaging three million, makes him the most-watched host on cable news.
docs.abstract: Television commentator Bill O'Reilly, most-watched host on cable news, says Pres Obama's health care speech was too long; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Encouraged by the billions of dollars in government funding, technology companies are making a big push to help bring computerized health records into small-office physician practices.

headline.main: Digital Health Records: The Hard Road Ahead

docs.abstract: The government's goal of computerizing patient medical records is a daunting challenge for reasons that have more to do with economics than technology.
docs.snippet: The government's goal of computerizing patient medical records is a daunting challenge for reasons that have more to do with economics than technology.

But when President Obama announced Wednesday night that his administration would establish pilot projects aimed at reducing lawsuits against doctors, Representative Charles Boustany Jr., the Louisiana Republican who delivered his party's response, sounded skeptical.

headline.main: Next Steps on Obama's Medical Malpractice Offer?

docs.abstract: In addressing medical malpractice, Mr. Obama is proposing a middle path.

docs.lead_paragraph: SUNY Downstate Medical Center -- the medical school that appears more than any other on the résumés of physicians currently practicing in New York City -- kicked off celebrations for its approaching 150th anniversary with a spirited convocation Thursday morning.

headline.main: SUNY Downstate Prepares for Its 150th Birthday

docs.abstract: SUNY Downstate Medical Center, which opened in 1860, is the medical school that appears more than any other on the résumés of physicians currently practicing in New York City.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Joe Wilson, Republican of South Carolina, discusses his apology to President Obama for his outburst during the President's speech on health care to Congress last night.

headline.sub: The Republican Discusses His Outburst in Obama's Speech

docs.lead_paragraph: In a follow-up speech to his address to Congress on Wednesday night, President Obama continued to press for an overhaul of the nation's health care system.

headline.main: Obama Speaks to Nurses on Health Care
headline.sub: President Cites Rising Number of the Uninsured

docs.snippet: In a follow-up speech to his address to Congress on Wednesday night, President Obama continued to press for an overhaul of the nation's health care system.
